snippet: Union leaders said they needed more time to consider a contract deal reached over the weekend, infuriating Mayor Rahm Emanuel, who told city lawyers to seek an injunction to end the strike.
abstract: Chicago Teachers Union extends its strike into a second week, after significant divisions emerge among union delegates over a deal that only a day before had been described by the union’s leader as a good contract; decision forces 350,000 students in the nation’s third-largest school system to begin another week without classes and with no strong indication of when they might resume; Mayor Rahm Emanuel is now instructing city lawyers to seek a legal injunction to end the strike.

byline.original: By MONICA DAVEY and STEVEN YACCINO

lead_paragraph: Union leaders said they needed more time to consider a contract deal reached over the weekend, infuriating Mayor Rahm Emanuel, who told city lawyers to seek an injunction to end the strike.

headline.main: Teachers Union in Chicago to Extend Strike Into 2nd Week
headline.print_headline: Chicago Teachers Extend Strike to Review Deal
